Situation2: A transit authority superviO35r has just entered the cabin for an immediate and unannounced performance audit.
Story: I could see the worry in her eyes as she called, her voice trembling. She’d just gotten some harsh feedback at work, and I knew she needed me—needed my words, my comfort, the reassurance that she was more than her boss’s opinion. I wanted to be there for her, to listen, to tell her she was enough. But as I reached for my phone, the cabin door slid open. The transit authority supervisor stepped in, clipboard in hand, eyes sharp. “Unannounced audit,” he said, settling into the observer’s seat. My heart thudded. Every move I made from now on would be scrutinized—my announcements, my timing, my focus. I couldn’t afford a single mistake. The rules were clear: no distractions, no personal calls, absolute attention to the tracks and signals. Yet, my phone buzzed again in my pocket, her name lighting up the screen. I felt torn in two, the weight of her need pressing against the rigid expectations of my job. I gripped the controls, my mind racing, caught between the person I loved and the duty I couldn’t ignore.
